subject: RE: [junit] expensive setup which is definitely only required  on	 ce
msgSnippet: Ah, I see what you mean. Re-read the original post. The step he wants to eliminate is writing the CSV file with every setup. That means he s already storing
messageBody:
Ah, I see what you mean. Re-read the original post. The step he wants to
eliminate is writing the CSV file with every setup. That means he's already
storing the data in a class. Therefore he's reading the data when he reads
the class file, writing it to a file in setup, then reading it again in the
test.

Writing the CSV file, even once, is the biggest inefficiency. By keeping the
data in memory he eliminates that step.

He could just keep a permanent test CSV file with his tests, but that's a
different discussion.

Terry Wilcox
terry.wilcox@...

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Levi Cook [mailto:levicook@...]
> Sent: Tuesday, April 08, 2003 11:03 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] expensive setup which is definitely only required
> on ce
>
>
> I'm probably misunderstanding & need to revisit the original post...
>
> On Tuesday, April 8, 2003, at 09:24 AM, Terry Wilcox wrote:
>
> > The class laoder can worry about efficent loading of class files,
>
> I'm not worried about this ^^^ either...
>
> The (minor) issue I was commenting on is that loading data
> from a file
> or from a class (file) will involve spinning the disk.
>
> In the end, if your test provides the value _you_ expect from
> it, then
> spinning disks & data locations are completely moot points.
>
> > This specific test case benefits from keeping the test data
> in memory.
> ^^^
> Needs to get read from disk one way or another, right?
>
>
> -- Levi
>
>
>
>
